skill.name: statsmodels
skill.description: Statistical models library for Python. Use when you need specific model classes (OLS, GLM, mixed models, ARIMA) with detailed diagnostics, residuals, and inference. Best for econometrics, time series, rigorous inference with coefficient tables. For guided statistical test selection with APA reporting use statistical-analysis.
skill.summary: Statistical models library for Python. Use when you need specific model classes (OLS, GLM, mixed mod...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 415 static findings are false positives. The scanned files are markdown documentation containing Python code examples. The analyzer misinterpreted markdown code block delimiters (```python) as shell commands, statistical function names as cryptographic algorithms, and common English words as C2 keywords. No malicious code exists in this skill.

content.value_statement: Statsmodels is Python's premier library for statistical modeling. Use it for regression analysis, time series forecasting, hypothesis testing, and generating publication-ready statistical tables with robust inference.
actual_capabilities: Fit OLS, GLM, and mixed-effects regression models with robust standard errors
Analyze time series with ARIMA, SARIMAX, VAR, and exponential smoothing models
Conduct hypothesis tests, diagnostic checks, and residual analysis
Generate confidence intervals, prediction intervals, and coefficient tables
Estimate discrete choice models including Logit, Probit, and count models
Perform model selection using AIC, BIC, and likelihood ratio tests
limitations: Does not include machine learning methods like neural networks or gradient boosting
Requires understanding of statistical methodology for proper interpretation
No automated model selection or hyperparameter tuning built-in

use_cases.title: Regression analysis
use_cases.description: Fit linear and generalized linear models with diagnostic tests and robust inference

use_cases.title: Econometric forecasting
use_cases.description: Build ARIMA and VAR models for economic time series with prediction intervals

use_cases.title: Hypothesis testing
use_cases.description: Conduct t-tests, ANOVA, and diagnostic tests with publication-ready tables

prompt_templates.title: Simple regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Fit an OLS regression model using statsmodels. Show how to add a constant, fit the model, and print the summary with coefficients, p-values, and confidence intervals.

prompt_templates.title: Time series forecast
prompt_templates.prompt: Use statsmodels to fit an ARIMA model to a time series. Include stationarity testing with ADF, model fitting, residual diagnostics, and 10-step ahead forecasts with prediction intervals.

prompt_templates.title: Logistic regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Fit a logistic regression using statsmodels Logit. Show how to interpret odds ratios, calculate marginal effects, and evaluate model performance with predicted probabilities.

prompt_templates.title: Model comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare two nested models using statsmodels. Show how to perform a likelihood ratio test, calculate AIC and BIC, and determine which model provides better fit.

output_examples.input: Fit an OLS regression with robust standard errors
output: Model: OLS with heteroskedasticity-consistent (HC3) standard errors
Coefficient for age: 0.42 (p=0.003) - significant positive effect

best_practices: Always add a constant with sm.add_constant() unless intentionally excluding the intercept
Check model assumptions using residual diagnostics before interpreting results
Use robust standard errors (HC0-HC3) when heteroskedasticity is present
anti_patterns: Fitting OLS on binary outcomes instead of using logistic regression
Ignoring model diagnostics and residual plots
Using Poisson regression when overdispersion indicates Negative Binomial is needed

faq.question: What is the difference between OLS and GLM?
faq.answer: OLS assumes normally distributed errors with constant variance. GLM extends this to non-normal outcomes using different distributions and link functions.

faq.question: How do I choose between ARIMA orders p, d, q?
faq.answer: Use ADF test for differencing order d. Examine ACF and PACF plots to identify p and q. Use AIC/BIC for model selection.

faq.question: When should I use robust standard errors?
faq.answer: Use robust SEs when diagnostic tests show heteroskedasticity or when clustering is present in your data structure.

faq.question: How do I interpret GLM coefficients?
faq.answer: Interpretation depends on the link function. For logit, exponentiate coefficients to get odds ratios. For log link, exponentiate for rate ratios.

faq.question: What diagnostics should I run after fitting a model?
faq.answer: Check residual normality, heteroskedasticity, autocorrelation, multicollinearity (VIF), and influential observations (Cook's distance).

faq.question: Can I use formulas like R?
faq.answer: Yes, use statsmodels.formula.api (smf) with R-style formulas like 'y ~ x1 + x2 + C(category)' for intuitive model specification.
